Title: Prove $\sin^2(x)<\sin(x^2)$ for $0<x<\sqrt{\frac{\pi}{2}}$
Content: I'm trying to prove  $\sin^2(x)<\sin(x^2)$ for $0<x<\sqrt{\frac{\pi}{2}}$. Attempt: This is equivalent to showing $f(x)=\sin(x^2)-\sin^2(x) = \sin(x^2)-\left(\frac{1-\cos(2x)}{2}\right)>0$. Since $f(0)=0$, if we show $f$ is increasing we are done. $f'(x) = 2x\cos(x^2)-\sin(2x)$ but I can't see why it's greater than zero.
AcceptedAnswer:
Finishing ellya's proof: For $x>1$ we have
$$\sin^2(x)< \sin(x) < \sin(x^2)$$
Since $\sin(x)$ is increasing in our domain. For $x\le1$:
$$\cos(x^2)\ge\cos(x), x>\sin(x)\implies 2x\cos(x^2)>2\sin(x)\cos(x)=\sin(2x)$$
